scenes.narration: Version 1.5 addresses top customer feedback with quality of life improvements. This is where you respond to what real users are telling you.
scenes.visualDescription: A Middle Eastern man entrepreneur sits hunched over a laptop in the innovation workshop, surrounded by sticky notes with customer quotes. He's meticulously implementing user feedback, adjusting the app's interface on his screen. Behind him, another entrepreneur is testing a physical prototype, representing the integration of digital and physical improvements.
scenes.templateHTML: Version 1.5: Improvements

scenes.heading: Version 2.0: Expansion
scenes.narration: Version 2.0 expands to adjacent problems with major new capabilities. But here's the critical warning...
scenes.visualDescription: A Hispanic woman entrepreneur gestures expansively towards a complex, multi-faceted product vision projected onto a large screen in the innovation workshop. The screen highlights expanded features and capabilities, but the image is slightly blurred. Colleagues are looking at her with expressions of both excitement and caution, as they plan the expansion.
scenes.templateHTML: Version 2.0: Expansion

scenes.heading: Version 2.0 Warning
scenes.narration: Don't plan Version 2.0 in detail until Version 1.0 is in customers' hands. What you learn from real usage will change everything.
scenes.visualDescription: An Asian man entrepreneur stares intently at a tablet displaying user analytics in the innovation workshop, face lit by the screen's glow. He wipes away a sketch of a planned feature that data now proves unnecessary. In the background, a half-finished 3D printed model sits abandoned, representing the need to adapt based on real-world usage.
scenes.templateHTML: Version 2.0 Warning

scenes.heading: The Now/Next/Later Framework
scenes.narration: Instead of detailed timelines that become obsolete, use the Now/Next/Later framework to organize your roadmap.
scenes.visualDescription: A White man entrepreneur is pointing at a "Now/Next/Later" framework diagram on a whiteboard. The "Now" section is clearly defined, "Next" is partially filled in, and "Later" is a cloud of ideas. A group of entrepreneurs stand around him listening, with varying degrees of agreement.
scenes.templateHTML: The Now/Next/Later Framework

scenes.heading: NOW: 4-8 Weeks
scenes.narration: NOW is the next 4-8 weeks. These are specific, committed features with resources already allocated. You're 90% confident these will ship.
scenes.visualDescription: A Black woman entrepreneur works on a detailed spec document on her laptop. The document outlines a specific feature for the "NOW" bucket, with clear acceptance criteria. A calendar next to her displays a 4-8 week timeline. The glow of the setting sun reflects off the focus in her eyes.
scenes.templateHTML: NOW: 4-8 Weeks

scenes.heading: NEXT: 2-3 Months
scenes.narration: NEXT is 2-3 months out. These are planned but flexible features. The general direction is set, but specifics depend on what you learn from NOW. You're 60-70% confident.
scenes.visualDescription: A Hispanic man entrepreneur is engaging in a brainstorming session with two other entrepreneurs. They are discussing features for the "NEXT" bucket. Sticky notes with tentative ideas are scattered across the table. One entrepreneur is looking out the glass wall towards the horizon, symbolizing future possibilities.
scenes.templateHTML: NEXT: 2-3 Months

scenes.heading: LATER: 3+ Months
scenes.narration: LATER is 3+ months out. This is your vision and direction — big ideas worth exploring. But at 20-30% confidence, it's more of a wish list than a commitment.
scenes.visualDescription: An Asian woman entrepreneur stands before a holographic projection of the "LATER" vision in the innovation workshop. The vision includes ambitious, futuristic features. She is looking at this vision with a sense of wonder and aspiration.
scenes.templateHTML: LATER: 3+ Months

scenes.heading: Requirements Tracker
scenes.narration: For each feature in your NOW bucket, create a simple requirements document. This keeps your team aligned and your work focused.
scenes.visualDescription: A Middle Eastern man entrepreneur is filling out a requirements tracker on his laptop. He meticulously enters feature names, user stories, and root causes into the tracker. A large display screen next to him shows the status of each feature in the NOW bucket.
scenes.templateHTML: Requirements Tracker

scenes.heading: Requirements Template
scenes.narration: Include the feature name, user story, which root cause it addresses, acceptance criteria, dependencies, and effort estimate. Keep it simple but complete.
scenes.visualDescription: A White woman entrepreneur reviews a detailed requirements template with her team, emphasizing the importance of completeness. The template includes fields for acceptance criteria, dependencies, and effort estimates. A 3D printer behind them begins printing a prototype, following the specifications outlined in the template.
scenes.templateHTML: Requirements Template

scenes.heading: Week 3 Complete!
scenes.narration: You've transformed customer insights into a clear product direction. You now have an MVP definition, prioritized features, and a flexible roadmap.
scenes.visualDescription: A South Asian man entrepreneur raises his arms in a celebratory gesture. He is surrounded by his team in the innovation workshop. Prototypes, sticky notes, and diagrams are scattered around the room, representing the culmination of their work in Week 3.
scenes.templateHTML: Week 3 Complete!

scenes.heading: Coming Next: Week 4
scenes.narration: Next week, you'll learn how to sell it — starting with the psychology of why people buy. Get ready to master the art of persuasion.
scenes.visualDescription: A Black woman entrepreneur looks towards a distant location in the mountains, bathed in sunset light. In her hands, she holds a book titled "The Art of Persuasion". The scene fades out as she anticipates the challenges and opportunities of Week 4.
scenes.templateHTML: Coming Next: Week 4

scenes.heading: The Murder House Problem
scenes.narration: Sales has a murder house problem. The word itself triggers images of pushy salesmen and manipulative tactics.
scenes.visualDescription: A White male entrepreneur sits alone on the porch of the alpine lodge, his back to the camera. The warm glow from inside illuminates his silhouette. He's staring out at a dense fog blanketing the mountains, a dilapidated miniature house made of popsicle sticks resting on the porch railing beside him. The string lights above flicker ominously, casting long, distorted shadows.
scenes.templateHTML: The Murder House Problem

scenes.heading: But That's Not Reality
scenes.narration: But that's not what sales actually is. The house is fine. The perception isn't.
scenes.visualDescription: An Asian woman entrepreneur, bundled in a cozy scarf, uses a small hammer to gently repair the popsicle stick house. She replaces broken windows and reinforces weak supports. Soft teal light emanates from her workshop inside the lodge, illuminating her focused expression. The fog outside has slightly lifted, revealing the snow-capped peaks in the distance.
scenes.templateHTML: But That's Not Reality

scenes.heading: What You Think Sales Is
scenes.narration: Most people imagine sales as talking people into things they don't want, using manipulation tactics.
scenes.visualDescription: A Middle Eastern man, wearing a perplexed expression, stands beside a crackling fireplace inside the lodge. He's surrounded by caricatures of stereotypical "pushy" salesmen sketched on parchment: fast-talking figures with slicked-back hair, pointing aggressively at the viewer. The room is dimly lit, emphasizing the unsettling drawings.
scenes.templateHTML: What You Think Sales Is

scenes.heading: The Wrong Archetype
scenes.narration: Being pushy and aggressive, closing at any cost. That's the archetype we all carry - and it's wrong.
scenes.visualDescription: A Hispanic woman entrepreneur dramatically tears one of the salesman caricatures from the wall, crumpling it in her hands. She throws the crumpled drawing into the fireplace, where it bursts into flames. Her expression is determined, a teal glow reflecting in her eyes from the fire. Other crumpled drawings litter the floor around her.
scenes.templateHTML: The Wrong Archetype

scenes.heading: What Sales Actually Is
scenes.narration: Real sales is problem discovery - understanding what someone actually needs.
scenes.visualDescription: A Black man entrepreneur sits at a wooden table inside the lodge, intently listening to a potential customer, a White woman, describe her business challenges. He’s taking notes on a digital tablet, his expression empathetic and focused. A steaming mug of herbal tea sits between them, suggesting a warm, collaborative atmosphere.
scenes.templateHTML: What Sales Actually Is

scenes.heading: Solution Matching
scenes.narration: Solution matching - connecting the right solution to the right problem.
scenes.visualDescription: The same Black man is now sketching furiously in his notebook, surrounded by diagrams and sticky notes. He’s visually connecting the customer’s problems to potential solutions with arrows and mind-map style groupings. Outside, the sun begins to peek through the clouds, casting a golden glow on the lodge.
scenes.templateHTML: Solution Matching

scenes.heading: Trust & Value
scenes.narration: Trust building and value communication - helping someone see how your solution helps them.
scenes.visualDescription: The Black man and White woman stand together on the lodge's porch, now bathed in the warm golden light of the setting sun. He gestures towards a blueprint of a customized solution he's designed, pointing out key features and benefits. She is smiling and nodding, her posture relaxed and receptive.
scenes.templateHTML: Trust & Value

scenes.heading: The 3 C's to Avoid
scenes.narration: Never convince - if you have to convince someone, you're talking to the wrong person.
scenes.visualDescription: An Asian man is shown walking away from a group gathered around a table inside the lodge. He's shaking his head, looking slightly disappointed. The others are gesturing emphatically, possibly trying to persuade him. The scene highlights his conscious choice to disengage.
scenes.templateHTML: The 3 C's to Avoid

scenes.heading: Never Co-opt
scenes.narration: Never co-opt or manipulate emotions. Creating false urgency destroys trust permanently.
scenes.visualDescription: A Middle Eastern woman stands on the porch, holding a smartphone with a timer running. She's looking directly at the camera with a stern expression. Around her, time-related props such as a ticking clock and hourglass are blurred and distorted, creating a sense of unease.
scenes.templateHTML: Never Co-opt

scenes.heading: Never Compel
scenes.narration: Never compel or pressure someone into a purchase. A reluctant customer becomes a resentful customer.
scenes.visualDescription: A Hispanic man is seated on a plush chair in front of the fireplace, looking pensive. He's gently pushing away a contract offered to him by another entrepreneur. A shadow looms large behind him, representing the pressure he's resisting.
scenes.templateHTML: Never Compel

scenes.heading: Sales as Service
scenes.narration: Sales isn't something you do TO people. It's something you do FOR people.
scenes.visualDescription: A Black woman entrepreneur is shown helping an elderly White man adjust his snowshoes on the porch of the lodge. She offers him a warm smile and a helping hand. A group of other entrepreneurs are preparing to embark on a hike, showcasing the spirit of collaboration and mutual support.
scenes.templateHTML: Sales as Service

scenes.heading: Service, Not Manipulation
scenes.narration: Helping them solve problems and make good decisions. When you approach it this way, it feels like service, not manipulation.
scenes.visualDescription: All of the entrepreneurs are gathered around a large wooden table in the lodge, sharing stories and celebrating their progress. The atmosphere is warm and convivial, filled with laughter and genuine connection. The lodge is brightly lit, showcasing the relationships they’ve built during their time there.
scenes.templateHTML: Service, Not Manipulation

scenes.heading: The Triangle Model
scenes.narration: The Triangle Model is simple, powerful, and transformative. It explains why some sales relationships thrive while others crash and burn.
scenes.visualDescription: A Hispanic woman entrepreneur sits at a rough-hewn wooden table inside the alpine lodge, sketching a triangle on a napkin with a charcoal pencil. String lights cast a warm glow on her focused expression. Scattered around her are crumpled napkins with similar diagrams, showing earlier attempts. The fireplace behind her crackles softly, casting dancing shadows on the walls. She seems lost in thought, biting the end of her pencil as she refines the triangle’s proportions.
scenes.templateHTML: The Triangle Model

scenes.heading: The Three Points
scenes.narration: There are three points: YOU, THEM, and IT. Every sales conversation exists within this triangle.
scenes.visualDescription: Three separate, glowing, abstract orbs float in the center of the alpine lodge’s main room, each representing a point in the triangle. One orb pulses with a warm orange light, another with a cool teal, and the third with a sunset amber. A South Asian man entrepreneur stands back, arms crossed, observing the interplay between the orbs, a contemplative look on his face. The light from the orbs reflects in his glasses, highlighting his analytical gaze.
scenes.templateHTML: The Three Points

scenes.heading: YOU - The Seller
scenes.narration: YOU is your expertise and credibility. It's what you bring to the table - your knowledge, experience, and genuine desire to help.
scenes.visualDescription: A White woman entrepreneur leans forward on the porch railing of the alpine lodge, gazing intently out at the misty mountain range. She holds a worn leather-bound journal, open to a page filled with notes about her company's expertise and credentials. The setting sun casts a long shadow, silhouetting her against the amber sky. A steaming mug sits beside her, neglected as she ponders her value proposition.
scenes.templateHTML: YOU - The Seller

scenes.heading: THEM - The Buyer
scenes.narration: THEM is your customer's needs and goals. This is what they care about most - their problems, their dreams, their situation.
scenes.visualDescription: A Black man entrepreneur sits in a comfortable armchair by the lodge's fireplace, listening intently through headphones to a customer interview recording on his laptop. His eyes are closed, and he nods slowly, absorbing the customer's needs and goals. Beside him on a small table are handwritten notes organized with color-coded sticky notes, reflecting the customer's pain points and aspirations.
scenes.templateHTML: THEM - The Buyer

scenes.heading: IT - The Solution
scenes.narration: IT is the product or service you're selling. It's the bridge between you and them. The magic is in how all three connect.
scenes.visualDescription: An Asian woman entrepreneur stands in front of a whiteboard inside the lodge, diagramming how her product connects the customer's needs with her company's expertise. She uses different colored markers to illustrate the flow of value. Projected on the whiteboard next to her diagram are customer testimonials praising the product's effectiveness. She gestures towards the board, explaining the solution's benefits to an unseen colleague.
scenes.templateHTML: IT - The Solution

scenes.heading: Connection: YOU to THEM
scenes.narration: The real power is in the connections between points. YOU to THEM is trust and rapport. Do they believe you understand them?
scenes.visualDescription: A Middle Eastern man entrepreneur sits face-to-face with a potential customer at a small table on the lodge’s porch. He leans forward, maintaining eye contact and actively listening, his body language conveying empathy and understanding. The customer, partially visible, seems engaged and receptive. A shared cup of tea sits between them, symbolizing the growing rapport.
scenes.templateHTML: Connection: YOU to THEM

scenes.heading: Connection: THEM to IT
scenes.narration: THEM to IT is whether your solution fits their problem. Does it actually solve what they need?
scenes.visualDescription: A White man entrepreneur sits hunched over his laptop at a picnic table outside the lodge, analyzing customer feedback data. He’s comparing the features of his product against customer reviews, highlighting areas of alignment and dissonance. The laptop screen glows with heatmaps illustrating feature usage and satisfaction scores. Frustration is etched on his face as he identifies gaps in the product's value proposition.
scenes.templateHTML: Connection: THEM to IT

scenes.heading: Connection: YOU to IT
scenes.narration: YOU to IT is your credibility to deliver. Are you the right person to provide this solution?
scenes.visualDescription: An African American woman entrepreneur stands confidently on the lodge's porch, presenting her company's credentials to an unseen client via a tablet. Her tone is assertive but friendly, conveying her expertise and trustworthiness. Behind her, a panoramic view of the mountain range underscores the reliability and strength of her company. Sunlight glints off the tablet screen, emphasizing her professionalism.
scenes.templateHTML: Connection: YOU to IT

scenes.heading: Problem: The Me Monster
scenes.narration: The Me Monster focuses only on themselves. They talk about their credentials, their experience, their company - but never learn what the customer actually needs.
scenes.visualDescription: A Hispanic man entrepreneur stands alone in a corner of the lodge, rambling incessantly about his company's awards and achievements to a disinterested-looking stuffed bear. His gestures are exaggerated, and he fails to notice the bear's lack of engagement. String lights twinkle overhead, casting an ironic glow on the one-sided conversation.
scenes.templateHTML: Problem: The Me Monster

scenes.heading: Problem: The Feature Dump
scenes.narration: The Feature Dump jumps straight to product without building trust. They list every feature, but the customer doesn't trust them yet, so they don't care.
scenes.visualDescription: An Asian man entrepreneur frantically throws product brochures at a bewildered-looking mannequin seated on a bench outside the lodge. He's rattling off features and specifications at lightning speed, completely ignoring the mannequin's blank stare. A stack of brochures lies scattered at the mannequin's feet, unread and unwanted.
scenes.templateHTML: Problem: The Feature Dump

scenes.heading: Problem: The Invisible Expert
scenes.narration: The Invisible Expert never establishes why they're the right person to help. They understand the problem perfectly but fail to show their credibility.
scenes.visualDescription: A Black woman entrepreneur stands silently in a dimly lit corner of the lodge, holding a glowing holographic projection of her company's solution. While her deep understanding of the problem is evident in the projection's intricacies, she fails to engage with anyone or explain her expertise. Her figure is partially obscured by shadows, emphasizing her invisibility.
scenes.templateHTML: Problem: The Invisible Expert

scenes.heading: Building the Perfect Triangle
scenes.narration: Great salespeople build all three connections in sequence. First, build rapport. Show genuine curiosity. Establish that you're a real person who cares.
scenes.visualDescription: A Middle Eastern woman entrepreneur sits cross-legged on a rug near the fireplace, conducting a one-on-one interview with a potential customer. She asks open-ended questions, attentively listening to the customer's responses. Her notebook is filled with detailed notes, capturing the nuances of the customer's needs and aspirations. The warm firelight creates a comfortable, intimate atmosphere.
scenes.templateHTML: Building the Perfect Triangle

scenes.heading: Complete the Triangle
scenes.narration: Then develop relevance - show how your solution addresses their specific problem. Finally, strengthen your credibility with relevant experience and success stories.
scenes.visualDescription: A South Asian man entrepreneur stands before a whiteboard in the lodge, presenting a concise and compelling demonstration of how his product solves a specific customer problem. He uses clear visuals and relatable examples to illustrate the value proposition. A small group of potential customers listens intently, nodding in understanding.
scenes.templateHTML: Complete the Triangle

scenes.heading: When All Three Connect
scenes.narration: When all three connections are strong, the sale happens naturally. The customer feels understood, sees the value, and trusts you to deliver.
scenes.visualDescription: A diverse group of entrepreneurs - Black woman, White man, Asian woman - stand together on the lodge's porch, laughing and celebrating a successful sale. They raise steaming mugs in a toast, their faces radiating joy and accomplishment. The setting sun paints the sky with vibrant colors, symbolizing the bright future ahead.
scenes.templateHTML: When All Three Connect

scenes.heading: People Buy for Their Reasons
scenes.narration: Here's the fundamental truth of sales: nobody cares about your product. They care about their problems.
scenes.visualDescription: A Middle Eastern woman entrepreneur sits on the Alpine Lodge porch swing, looking away from a product demo on her laptop. She's frowning and gesturing dismissively with one hand. The camera focuses on the reflection in her sunglasses, showing a distorted image of the laptop screen with the product's features highlighted, emphasizing her disinterest in the product itself, aligning with the narration. A steaming mug sits beside her on the porch railing.
scenes.templateHTML: People Buy for Their Reasons

scenes.heading: Their Goals, Their Aspirations
scenes.narration: They care about their goals, their fears and aspirations. Your product is just a means to their end.
scenes.visualDescription: A Black man entrepreneur leans back in a comfortable armchair inside the Alpine Lodge, eyes closed, a contented smile on his face. He's surrounded by images projected onto the wooden walls—a graduation ceremony, a family vacation, a new house. These visuals represent his goals and aspirations. He wears noise-cancelling headphones, subtly illustrating that he's tuning out the product details and focusing on his own internal motivations.
scenes.templateHTML: Their Goals, Their Aspirations

scenes.heading: The Friedman Model
scenes.narration: Milton Friedman identified four ways money is spent. Each creates different buying behavior.
scenes.visualDescription: A Hispanic woman entrepreneur stands at a whiteboard inside the Alpine Lodge, diagramming the Friedman Model with colored markers. She's using different colored markers to differentiate the 4 quadrants. A group of other entrepreneurs are seated around a coffee table nearby, observing her presentation and nodding in understanding.
scenes.templateHTML: The Friedman Model

scenes.heading: Spending Your Own Money
scenes.narration: The key question: whose money is being spent, and for whom? When it's your money, you care about cost.
scenes.visualDescription: An Asian man entrepreneur is hunched over a laptop at a rustic wooden table in the Alpine Lodge, looking stressed. He's meticulously comparing prices and features of two competing software packages in a spreadsheet. A half-empty coffee mug sits beside him, showing the late hour. The scene highlights his careful consideration of cost when spending his own money.
scenes.templateHTML: Spending Your Own Money

scenes.heading: Spending Others' Money
scenes.narration: When spending others' money on yourself, quality matters most. When spending others' money on others, accountability is lowest.
scenes.visualDescription: A White woman entrepreneur sits by the fireplace in the Alpine Lodge, relaxed and chatting on her phone. She gestures expansively, seemingly unconcerned with the cost of the premium service she's discussing. A room service menu lies open on the table beside her, suggesting she's using company funds.
scenes.templateHTML: Spending Others' Money

scenes.heading: B2C: Business to Consumer
scenes.narration: B2C is emotional and fast. Individual decision makers, shorter sales cycles, and personal benefit drives the purchase.
scenes.visualDescription: A Black man entrepreneur is speaking enthusiastically to a group of individuals gathered around a cozy seating area in the Alpine Lodge. His gestures are large and engaging, he is using a tablet to show an infographic showing the excitement of a customer using his company’s product. The atmosphere is warm and inviting, reflecting the emotional nature of B2C sales.
scenes.templateHTML: B2C: Business to Consumer

scenes.heading: B2B: Business to Business
scenes.narration: B2B is rational with multiple stakeholders. Longer sales cycles, higher price points, and ROI drives the decision.
scenes.visualDescription: An Asian woman entrepreneur is engaged in a serious discussion with three other individuals around a conference table inside the Alpine Lodge. One of the individuals is pointing at a ROI chart on a monitor, while the others listen intently. The atmosphere is formal and professional, reflecting the rational nature of B2B sales.
scenes.templateHTML: B2B: Business to Business

scenes.heading: B2G: Business to Government
scenes.narration: B2G is compliance-driven with formal procurement. Each requires a fundamentally different approach.
scenes.visualDescription: A Middle Eastern man entrepreneur in a sharp suit sits at a table covered with legal documents in a private room within the Alpine Lodge. He's meticulously reviewing a contract with a stern expression. The room is dimly lit, emphasizing the serious and compliance-driven nature of B2G sales. The lighting is more cold than other scenes.
scenes.templateHTML: B2G: Business to Government

scenes.heading: The Buyer's Journey
scenes.narration: Every buyer goes through predictable stages. Understanding where they are determines how you should engage.
scenes.visualDescription: A Hispanic woman entrepreneur stands in the center of the Alpine Lodge, illuminated by a soft spotlight. Projected around her are four sequential images showing the Buyer's Journey: a confused person scratching their head, someone researching on a laptop, a person confidently making a purchase, and finally a satisfied customer using the product.
scenes.templateHTML: The Buyer's Journey

scenes.heading: Awareness & Consideration
scenes.narration: First, Awareness: they realize they have a problem. Then Consideration: they're actively comparing options.
scenes.visualDescription: A White man entrepreneur is standing on the porch of the Alpine Lodge, looking through binoculars at the distant mountain peaks. He is unaware of a small obstacle in his path. A split screen shows, on one side, a person looking confused, representing the "Awareness" stage, and on the other side, a person comparing products on a laptop, representing the "Consideration" stage.
scenes.templateHTML: Awareness & Consideration

scenes.heading: Decision & Action
scenes.narration: Then Decision: they've narrowed options and are ready to choose. Finally Action: they buy and begin using your solution.
scenes.visualDescription: An African American woman entrepreneur is confidently striding toward the door of the Alpine Lodge, holding a signed contract. One image shows a person selecting a product, while another shows the same person happily using the product. The overall effect suggests a decision has been made and action is being taken.
scenes.templateHTML: Decision & Action

scenes.heading: Know Your Buyer
scenes.narration: The best salespeople are psychologists first and product experts second. They understand that buying decisions are made in the buyer's head.
scenes.visualDescription: An Asian man entrepreneur sits across from a potential customer in a quiet nook of the Alpine Lodge. He's leaning forward, listening intently, with a warm, empathetic expression. The lighting is soft and focuses on the buyer's face, conveying the importance of understanding the buyer's perspective.
scenes.templateHTML: Know Your Buyer

scenes.heading: Meet Them Where They Are
scenes.narration: Buying decisions are made based on the buyer's logic, within the buyer's context. Your job is to understand that context.
scenes.visualDescription: A White woman entrepreneur is sitting on the porch, sipping tea and observing the landscape. She's smiling thoughtfully, as if internalizing the buyer's context. A journal lies open in her lap, filled with handwritten notes and diagrams, suggesting she's actively working to understand the customer's perspective.
scenes.templateHTML: Meet Them Where They Are

scenes.heading: Know Your Customer Deeply
scenes.narration: An Ideal Customer Profile should be so specific you could pick them out of a crowd.
scenes.visualDescription: A Middle Eastern woman entrepreneur, wearing a cozy sweater, sits on a porch swing at the Alpine Lodge, intently studying a photo album filled with pictures of diverse individuals. She's tracing connections between their faces and handwritten notes detailing their unique aspirations, with a soft smile suggesting she recognizes them intimately. Warm light spills from the lodge windows, illuminating the scene.
scenes.templateHTML: Know Your Customer Deeply

scenes.heading: Beyond Surface Level
scenes.narration: Not because of how they look, but because of how they think, what they fear, and what they aspire to.
scenes.visualDescription: A White man entrepreneur leans back in a comfortable armchair near the lodge fireplace, eyes closed in thought. An ethereal projection of a human brain hovers above him, with glowing pathways highlighting thought patterns and emotional responses. Surrounding him are books with titles like "Understanding Fears" and "The Power of Aspirations." He's surrounded by a gentle, warm glow.
scenes.templateHTML: Beyond Surface Level

scenes.heading: Your ICP Purpose
scenes.narration: It's not about excluding customers — it's about knowing exactly who you're talking to.
scenes.visualDescription: An Asian woman entrepreneur stands at a large wooden table in the center of the Alpine Lodge, gesturing towards a whiteboard covered in sticky notes. She's addressing two other entrepreneurs, one looking attentively, the other scribbling notes. The whiteboard displays a Venn diagram illustrating how the Ideal Customer Profile helps focus the conversation.
scenes.templateHTML: Your ICP Purpose

scenes.heading: ICP Components
scenes.narration: There are four essential components to a complete Ideal Customer Profile.
scenes.visualDescription: A Black man entrepreneur sits at a cozy table in the Alpine Lodge, using a quill pen to write in a leather-bound journal titled "Ideal Customer Profile." Four glowing orbs representing the essential ICP components – Demographics, Psychographics, Behaviors, and Buying Triggers – float around him, connected by beams of teal light. A cup of steaming tea sits beside the journal.
scenes.templateHTML: ICP Components

scenes.heading: Demographics & Psychographics
scenes.narration: Demographics tell you who they are. Psychographics tell you why they buy.
scenes.visualDescription: A Hispanic woman entrepreneur studies two holographic projections side-by-side within the Alpine Lodge. One projection shows a demographic profile (age, location, occupation) radiating outward in rings. The other shows a swirling vortex of psychographic data (values, fears, aspirations). She touches the psychographic projection with curiosity, deepening the glow.
scenes.templateHTML: Demographics & Psychographics

scenes.heading: Behaviors & Buying Triggers
scenes.narration: Behaviors show where to find them. Buying triggers reveal when they're ready.
scenes.visualDescription: An Asian man entrepreneur sits at a small writing desk in a nook of the lodge, surrounded by maps and location-based tools. Teal beams emanate from tablets and connect to a network of glowing icons representing behaviors. Overlaid on the maps are radar-like pulses highlighting areas indicating buying triggers, showing where and when customers are ready to engage.
scenes.templateHTML: Behaviors & Buying Triggers

scenes.heading: Case Study: Meet Rachel
scenes.narration: Let's look at a real example. Meet Rachel, a service-based business owner aged 35 to 45.
scenes.visualDescription: A White woman entrepreneur stands on the porch of the Alpine Lodge, holding a tablet that displays a photo of "Rachel." The screen is split, showing a professional headshot on one side and a sketched portrait on the other, capturing Rachel's personality. She is smiling warmly, as if greeting Rachel as a friend.
scenes.templateHTML: Case Study: Meet Rachel

scenes.heading: Rachel's Psychographics
scenes.narration: Rachel values freedom but secretly fears she's not a real business person. She believes hard work should be enough.
scenes.visualDescription: A Black woman entrepreneur sits on a plush armchair in the Alpine Lodge, eyes closed as she visualizes Rachel. Overlaid on her form are translucent projections displaying "Rachel's" values (freedom), fears (not a real business person), and beliefs (hard work). Teal lines connect these elements, illustrating their interconnectedness.
scenes.templateHTML: Rachel's Psychographics

scenes.heading: Rachel's Buying Triggers
scenes.narration: Rachel is triggered to buy when she realizes hard work alone won't get her where she wants to go.
scenes.visualDescription: A Middle Eastern man entrepreneur is speaking to someone out of frame from a comfortable armchair near a crackling fire. A hologram of Rachel appears between them, looking initially frustrated, then suddenly illuminated with an idea. The hologram brightens as it visualizes her trigger: realizing hard work alone isn't enough.
scenes.templateHTML: Rachel's Buying Triggers

scenes.heading: Crafting Your Hooks
scenes.narration: Once you know your ICP, you can craft hooks that speak directly to them.
scenes.visualDescription: A Hispanic woman entrepreneur, surrounded by notepads and pens, sits at a wooden table in the Alpine Lodge, deeply focused on crafting hooks. Teal lines connect words and phrases, forming compelling statements. A faint holographic target floats above the table, symbolizing the ICP that the hooks aim to capture.
scenes.templateHTML: Crafting Your Hooks

scenes.heading: Online Hook Formula
scenes.narration: Online hooks follow the WHO + WHAT + WHY formula: I help WHO to do WHAT so they can WHY.
scenes.visualDescription: An Asian man entrepreneur stands by a chalkboard inside the Alpine Lodge where the "WHO + WHAT + WHY" formula is written in teal chalk. He's gesturing towards the formula with a piece of chalk, emphasizing each component. Holographic examples of effective online hooks float around the board, demonstrating the concept.
scenes.templateHTML: Online Hook Formula

scenes.heading: Face-to-Face Hook
scenes.narration: Face-to-face hooks start with a problem they'll immediately recognize. Get them nodding before you introduce yourself.
scenes.visualDescription: A White woman entrepreneur leans forward, smiling genuinely, as she practices her face-to-face hook in front of a mirror within the lodge. The mirror reflects not only her image but also a speech bubble containing a question designed to elicit a nod of recognition from her target audience. String lights illuminate the porch visible through the window behind her.
scenes.templateHTML: Face-to-Face Hook

scenes.heading: Always Have a B-Side
scenes.narration: Your ICP is a hypothesis you're constantly refining. Always have a B-side — a secondary customer type.
scenes.visualDescription: A Black man entrepreneur sits on the lodge porch, examining two separate profiles displayed on his tablet. One is highlighted in vibrant colors, representing the primary ICP. The other, the "B-side," is rendered in softer, more muted tones. He's thoughtfully comparing the two, a concerned yet contemplative expression on his face.
scenes.templateHTML: Always Have a B-Side

scenes.heading: Why Have a B-Side?
scenes.narration: This gives you flexibility and helps you discover unexpected product-market fit.
scenes.visualDescription: A Middle Eastern woman entrepreneur is walking in the snow outside the lodge, looking up at a distant mountain peak with an analytical gaze. A swirling wind carries glowing snowflakes, each representing a different customer segment. The snowflakes diverge and converge, symbolizing the process of discovering product-market fit.
scenes.templateHTML: Why Have a B-Side?

scenes.heading: ICP as Hypothesis
scenes.narration: Your ICP isn't set in stone. It's a hypothesis you're constantly refining based on who actually buys, stays, and refers.
scenes.visualDescription: A Hispanic man entrepreneur sits at the edge of the lodge porch, using a digital pen to adjust the parameters of a holographic ICP model displayed on a large screen. He's refining demographic sliders, psychographic scores, and behavioral patterns based on new customer feedback. The model shifts and evolves with each adjustment.
scenes.templateHTML: ICP as Hypothesis

scenes.heading: How Businesses Generate Income
scenes.narration: Revenue model is one of the most important decisions you'll make as an entrepreneur.
scenes.visualDescription: A Middle Eastern woman entrepreneur stands confidently on the highest level of the observation tower, arms crossed, gazing out at the panoramic view. Holographic projections of various revenue models – product sales, subscriptions, services – swirl around her head, each with a different color glow. The scene highlights the vastness of choices and the importance of selecting the right one.
scenes.templateHTML: How Businesses Generate Income

scenes.heading: What Revenue Model Determines
scenes.narration: It determines how you get paid and how customers perceive the value you provide.
scenes.visualDescription: An Asian man entrepreneur is leaning over a holographic display showing a customer journey map. Teal lines illustrate the flow of value exchange. He traces a path with his finger, thoughtfully considering how customers perceive the business's offerings. Another entrepreneur looks on, offering guidance.
scenes.templateHTML: What Revenue Model Determines

scenes.heading: Building Your Business Foundation
scenes.narration: Ultimately, it shapes what kind of business you're building.
scenes.visualDescription: A White woman entrepreneur is sketching on a glass whiteboard in the observation tower, outlining a business model canvas. Her team reviews the concept, nodding in agreement. The whiteboard is illuminated with teal lighting, accentuating the foundational elements of the business being built.
scenes.templateHTML: Building Your Business Foundation

scenes.heading: The Six Fundamental Models
scenes.narration: There are six fundamental revenue models that drive business success.
scenes.visualDescription: A Black man entrepreneur is using a gesture-controlled interface to manipulate six glowing orbs, each representing a fundamental revenue model. He's carefully arranging them to explore potential combinations and strategies. The panoramic windows behind him showcase a vibrant sunset, symbolizing new opportunities.
scenes.templateHTML: The Six Fundamental Models

scenes.heading: Models 1-3
scenes.narration: Product Sales, Subscriptions, and Services — these are the first three models.
scenes.visualDescription: A Hispanic woman entrepreneur points to three highlighted segments of a holographic pie chart labeled "Revenue Models". These segments represent product sales, subscriptions, and services. She is explaining the breakdown to her team of two, while the others are listening intently, their faces lit by the teal glow.
scenes.templateHTML: Models 1-3

scenes.heading: Models 4-6
scenes.narration: Transactions or Marketplace, Licensing, and Advertising complete the six.
scenes.visualDescription: An Asian woman entrepreneur gestures towards a holographic display divided into three sections: "Transactions/Marketplace", "Licensing", and "Advertising". The three sections glow slightly brighter than the rest of the interface. She turns toward a colleague, emphasizing the strategic importance of the models.
scenes.templateHTML: Models 4-6

scenes.heading: Primary + Supporting Models
scenes.narration: Most successful companies use one primarily with one or two supporting models.
scenes.visualDescription: A White man entrepreneur stands before a complex holographic model, with one revenue stream highlighted in amber and two others in teal. He emphasizes the importance of a primary revenue stream, while the other models are supporting, creating a layered approach.
scenes.templateHTML: Primary + Supporting Models

scenes.heading: Subscriptions: The Holy Grail
scenes.narration: Subscriptions are the holy grail for investors because of predictable, compounding growth.
scenes.visualDescription: A Black woman entrepreneur stares intently at a glowing subscription graph projected onto the panoramic window of the observation tower. The graph shows a steady upward trajectory, emphasizing predictable growth. The reflection of the graph is visible in her eyes.
scenes.templateHTML: Subscriptions: The Holy Grail

scenes.heading: Why Investors Love Subscriptions
scenes.narration: Netflix, Salesforce, and Dollar Shave Club all built empires on recurring revenue.
scenes.visualDescription: A Hispanic man entrepreneur uses a pair of augmented reality binoculars to view three digital buildings overlaid on the landscape: Netflix, Salesforce, and Dollar Shave Club headquarters. Each building has a stylized representation of its logo and revenue numbers.
scenes.templateHTML: Why Investors Love Subscriptions

scenes.heading: Subscription Benefits
scenes.narration: Recurring revenue means predictable growth and higher company valuations.
scenes.visualDescription: An Asian entrepreneur is presenting a holographic slide on subscription benefits to an investor shown as a floating head. The slide highlights "Predictable Growth" and "Higher Valuations" in bold teal text. The investor is nodding, seeming impressed.
scenes.templateHTML: Subscription Benefits

scenes.heading: Hybrid Revenue Models
scenes.narration: Most successful companies stack models strategically, combining multiple revenue streams.
scenes.visualDescription: A White woman entrepreneur is stacking several holographic blocks representing different revenue models, illustrating the concept of hybrid revenue models. Each block has a unique icon: a shopping cart, a subscription icon, and a service hand.
scenes.templateHTML: Hybrid Revenue Models

scenes.heading: Amazon's Five Models
scenes.narration: Amazon uses product sales, marketplace transactions, Prime subscriptions, AWS services, and advertising.
scenes.visualDescription: A Black man entrepreneur stands in front of a holographic pyramid, with five sides representing Amazon's revenue models: product sales, marketplace transactions, Prime subscriptions, AWS services, and advertising. Each side is labeled and animated.
scenes.templateHTML: Amazon's Five Models

scenes.heading: Start Simple, Add Later
scenes.narration: But start simple — master one model before adding complexity.
scenes.visualDescription: A Hispanic woman entrepreneur is pointing to a single, brightly lit holographic icon representing a product sale. Other revenue model icons are dimmed in the background, emphasizing the importance of starting simple before adding complexity.
scenes.templateHTML: Start Simple, Add Later

scenes.heading: The Invisible Revenue Model
scenes.narration: Your revenue model should feel invisible to customers.
scenes.visualDescription: An Asian man entrepreneur is observing customers using his product through a telescope aimed at a distant city, focusing on their natural interaction with the offering. Holographic overlays highlight the seamless integration of the revenue model, making it almost imperceptible.
scenes.templateHTML: The Invisible Revenue Model

scenes.heading: Match Customer Expectations
scenes.narration: It should match how they naturally want to buy what you're selling.
scenes.visualDescription: A White woman entrepreneur adjusts a holographic slider to align her business's revenue model with customer expectations. The slider has two labels: "Business Model" and "Customer Expectations." Teal light fills the room as the two metrics align.
scenes.templateHTML: Match Customer Expectations

scenes.heading: Key Questions to Ask
scenes.narration: Ask: what do you deliver, how often do they need you, and where is value created?
scenes.visualDescription: A Black woman entrepreneur stands facing the viewer, with three questions hovering in the air around her: "What do you deliver?", "How often do they need you?", and "Where is value created?". The questions glow with a warm amber light, encouraging contemplation.
scenes.templateHTML: Key Questions to Ask

scenes.heading: Pricing as Signal
scenes.narration: Pricing isn't just a number. It's a signal that tells customers what to expect and whether you're the right fit.
scenes.visualDescription: A Middle Eastern woman entrepreneur stands at the highest level of the observation tower, gazing through a large telescope. She's not looking at stars, but at a crowd of diverse potential customers projected onto a holographic display in front of her. Teal light highlights the faces of customers who match her ideal profile, while others are dimmed. She's adjusting the telescope's focus, subtly altering the signal sent by her pricing.
scenes.templateHTML: Pricing as Signal

scenes.heading: More Than a Number
scenes.narration: Most entrepreneurs leave money on the table by defaulting to competitor pricing minus a little bit.
scenes.visualDescription: A White man entrepreneur sits slumped at a workstation in the tower, surrounded by data readouts. He's using a basic calculator to perform a simple cost-plus calculation. Through the panoramic windows, we see competitor towers with prominently displayed prices, suggesting he's merely matching them. He looks frustrated, like he knows he's missing something.
scenes.templateHTML: More Than a Number

scenes.heading: Price Sends Messages
scenes.narration: Price too low and you attract the wrong customers. Price too high without justification and you lose deals you should win.
scenes.visualDescription: A Hispanic woman entrepreneur paces anxiously across a glass platform within the observation tower. On one side, a projection shows a group of customers turning away, disappointed, from a high-priced product. On the other, a different group is shown arguing over a deeply discounted but ultimately low-quality offering. The tower's structure seems to strain under the weight of these conflicting signals.
scenes.templateHTML: Price Sends Messages

scenes.heading: Six Pricing Strategies
scenes.narration: There are six main pricing strategies every entrepreneur should know.
scenes.visualDescription: An East Asian man entrepreneur stands confidently before a holographic display listing the six pricing strategies. Each strategy is represented by a miniature architectural model related to the tower: a cost-plus foundation, a competitive mirroring structure, a penetration starting point, a premium pinnacle, a value-based elevator, and a freemium open door. He gestures toward them, as if explaining their interconnectedness.
scenes.templateHTML: Six Pricing Strategies

scenes.heading: Cost-Based Strategies
scenes.narration: Cost-Plus adds a markup to your costs. Competitive pricing positions you relative to others in the market.
scenes.visualDescription: A Black man entrepreneur is working with an engineer at a workstation inside the observation tower. They're both looking at a cost breakdown displayed on a monitor. A teal light highlights the high cost of materials. The entrepreneur scratches his head, seemingly stuck on how to get the final price where it should be without affecting his profit margin.
scenes.templateHTML: Cost-Based Strategies

scenes.heading: Growth Strategies
scenes.narration: Penetration pricing starts low to gain market share. Premium pricing signals quality and exclusivity.
scenes.visualDescription: A South Asian woman entrepreneur is presenting to a small group inside the observation tower. She's pointing to a holographic projection of a rocket launching into space, representing penetration pricing for rapid market entry. A second projection shows an exclusive, high-end watch, symbolizing premium pricing, held up under glass. The group seems intrigued by both options.
scenes.templateHTML: Growth Strategies

scenes.heading: Value-Based & Freemium
scenes.narration: Value-based prices on outcomes delivered. Freemium offers free basics with paid upgrades. Value-based is where the real money is.
scenes.visualDescription: A White woman entrepreneur is on a video call with a customer, demonstrating the value of her service. The customer is smiling and nodding as they see a clear projection of the results. She is using a touch screen to display a visual representation of a value-based pricing model and a freemium model to show the client the difference in value and quality of services.
scenes.templateHTML: Value-Based & Freemium

scenes.heading: The Critical Difference
scenes.narration: Let's compare value-based and cost-plus pricing with a real example.
scenes.visualDescription: A Black woman is looking at an image of the tower on the holographic display and analyzing the different perspectives of cost-plus and value-based pricing in comparison. She has a thoughtful and analytic look in her eyes.
scenes.templateHTML: The Critical Difference

scenes.heading: The Cost-Plus Trap
scenes.narration: A consultant works 10 hours at $200 per hour. That's $2,000 total.
scenes.visualDescription: A Hispanic man entrepreneur is sitting at his desk, looking stressed. On the holographic display is an image of an hourly rate invoice. A teal light highlights the short time spent on the project, making him feel bad about charging more.
scenes.templateHTML: The Cost-Plus Trap

scenes.heading: The Value Perspective
scenes.narration: But what if that work saves the client $100,000? Suddenly $20,000 is a bargain — still 80% savings for them.
scenes.visualDescription: An East Asian entrepreneur is looking out the panoramic window of the observation tower at a business owner looking overjoyed. On the holographic display, he is able to see the value that the consultant brought to the business owner and the amount of money saved. A teal light highlights the profit being brought into the business by the consultant.
scenes.templateHTML: The Value Perspective

scenes.heading: 10x the Revenue
scenes.narration: Same work, ten times the revenue. That's the power of value-based pricing.
scenes.visualDescription: A Middle Eastern woman entrepreneur stands in the tower's central hub, her arms outstretched, surrounded by swirling holographic representations of revenue growth. The tower seems to resonate with the energy of value-based pricing, the teal lights pulsating faster. She is smiling with satisfaction.
scenes.templateHTML: 10x the Revenue

scenes.heading: Imposter Syndrome Pricing
scenes.narration: Watch out for imposter syndrome pricing — charging low because you don't feel worthy. Your price should reflect value to customers, not your self-esteem.
scenes.visualDescription: A South Asian man entrepreneur stares into a reflective pane of glass, his own worried face superimposed over a low price tag. The tower seems to darken around him, reflecting his self-doubt. A holographic display shows the true value of his product far exceeding the price he's considering.
scenes.templateHTML: Imposter Syndrome Pricing

scenes.heading: One-Size-Fits-All
scenes.narration: Also avoid one-size-fits-all pricing when you could segment. Different customers have different willingness to pay.
scenes.visualDescription: A White woman entrepreneur stands before three separate holographic projections, each showing a different customer segment with varying willingness to pay. One segment is willing to pay a premium, another is price-sensitive, and the third is somewhere in between. She is using a touch screen to adjust pricing levels for each segment.
scenes.templateHTML: One-Size-Fits-All

scenes.heading: Never Raising Prices
scenes.narration: And never raising prices even as your value increases and costs go up. Existing customers often accept increases better than you expect.
scenes.visualDescription: A Black man entrepreneur nervously adjusts the knobs on a holographic control panel, gradually increasing the price of his product. Behind him, a group of his loyal customers appears on a projection, smiling and giving thumbs-up, signaling their acceptance of the price increase. The tower's structure seems to strengthen as the price rises.
scenes.templateHTML: Never Raising Prices

scenes.heading: Your Price Is a Message
scenes.narration: The right price attracts ideal customers and repels poor fits. The wrong price creates constant friction.
scenes.visualDescription: A Hispanic woman entrepreneur observes two distinct groups of potential customers projected onto the observation tower's exterior. One group, bathed in teal light, is eagerly approaching. The other, shrouded in shadow, is turning away. The tower itself seems to filter the crowd, attracting those who align with her pricing.
scenes.templateHTML: Your Price Is a Message

scenes.heading: What Matters
scenes.narration: Remember: the customer doesn't care how hard you worked. They care what the result is worth to them.
scenes.visualDescription: An East Asian man entrepreneur stands near a panoramic window, watching a construction worker diligently building a skyscraper. But the skyscraper is only half-finished. The entrepreneur points to a holographic display showing the completed skyscraper (the result), not the labor.
scenes.templateHTML: What Matters

scenes.heading: Price Accordingly
scenes.narration: Price accordingly. Your price tells the market who you are and who you're for.
scenes.visualDescription: A Middle Eastern woman entrepreneur stands at the apex of the observation tower, silhouetted against the sunset. She adjusts a holographic beacon, sending a clear, strong signal into the market. The tower glows with teal light, projecting a clear message: "We are here for those who value quality and results."
scenes.templateHTML: Price Accordingly

scenes.heading: The Numbers That Matter
scenes.narration: You can have the best product in the world and still fail if you don't understand a few key numbers.
scenes.visualDescription: A Middle Eastern woman entrepreneur, in a stylish jumpsuit, stands confidently on the highest level of the Observation Tower, gazing out through a panoramic window. She holds a tablet displaying a simplified dashboard of three key metrics (margin, burn, runway) rendered as stylized circular gauges. Teal light emanates from the screen, highlighting her focused expression. Below, the complex latticework of the tower's glass and steel frame recedes into the misty landscape.
scenes.templateHTML: The Numbers That Matter

scenes.heading: Three Core Metrics
scenes.narration: You need to master three core metrics: gross margin, burn rate, and runway.
scenes.visualDescription: A Black man entrepreneur sits at a circular holographic display table on a mid-level platform within the Observation Tower, intently manipulating 3D projections of stylized coins (representing revenue) being consumed by flames (representing expenses). He drags more coins toward the flames, experimenting with expense reduction. Teal lines trace the flow of funds. Other entrepreneurs are visible through glass walls in the background, focused on their own data.
scenes.templateHTML: Three Core Metrics

scenes.heading: Gross Margin Formula
scenes.narration: Gross margin tells you how much you keep from each sale after direct costs.
scenes.visualDescription: An Asian woman entrepreneur leans against a large whiteboard inside the Observation Tower, the whiteboard covered in a sprawling gross margin formula written in teal marker. She's pointing to a specific variable (Cost of Goods Sold) with a stylus, explaining it to a holographic projection of a younger version of herself, demonstrating how it impacts the final margin.
scenes.templateHTML: Gross Margin Formula

scenes.heading: Margin Benchmarks
scenes.narration: Below 30% is extremely tight. 50 to 70% is healthy. Above 70% is excellent and investor-attractive.
scenes.visualDescription: A White man entrepreneur peers through a high-powered telescope mounted on an external viewing platform of the Observation Tower. The telescope's display shows a segmented pie chart representing margin benchmarks (tight, healthy, excellent), with each section color-coded. His hand hovers over an adjustment knob, as if fine-tuning his understanding of the data. The orange sunset paints the distant mountain peaks.
scenes.templateHTML: Margin Benchmarks

scenes.heading: What is Burn Rate?
scenes.narration: Burn rate is how much cash you spend each month to keep the business running.
scenes.visualDescription: A Hispanic woman entrepreneur stands beside a glowing holographic projector inside the tower, the projector casting a detailed image of a stylized "cash pile" being rapidly consumed by a stylized "fire" (representing burn rate). She gestures with concern towards the depleting cash, as though calculating the speed of the burn. The floor beneath is glass, revealing lower levels of the tower.
scenes.templateHTML: What is Burn Rate?

scenes.heading: Gross vs Net Burn
scenes.narration: Gross burn is total expenses. Net burn subtracts your revenue. The goal is to get net burn to zero — that's breakeven.
scenes.visualDescription: A South Asian man entrepreneur is using a gesture-based interface to compare two side-by-side holographic projections: one depicting "Gross Burn" (large flames) and another depicting "Net Burn" (smaller flames, with some revenue offsetting expenses). Teal lines connect the two projections, illustrating the deduction of revenue. He's nodding in understanding, a thoughtful expression on his face.
scenes.templateHTML: Gross vs Net Burn

scenes.heading: What is Runway?
scenes.narration: Runway is cash in bank divided by net burn rate. It's your window to become profitable or raise more money.
scenes.visualDescription: A Black woman entrepreneur stands in the center of a circular room within the Observation Tower. A beam of teal light shines down upon her, illuminating her face as she contemplates a holographic representation of a landing strip (runway) extending out into the distance. The length of the runway shrinks with each passing second, emphasizing the limited timeframe.
scenes.templateHTML: What is Runway?

scenes.heading: Runway Benchmarks
scenes.narration: Less than 6 months is danger zone. 12 to 18 months is comfortable. 18 plus is ideal — focus on growth, not survival.
scenes.visualDescription: A White woman entrepreneur sits at a control panel within the Observation Tower, reviewing three holographic displays. Each display represents a runway benchmark (danger zone, comfortable, ideal), visualized as different lengths of a stylized path. She touches the "ideal" path, her expression reflecting determination and growth.
scenes.templateHTML: Runway Benchmarks

scenes.heading: What Investors Expect
scenes.narration: Investors don't expect you to be profitable yet. They expect you to understand your numbers.
scenes.visualDescription: A Middle Eastern man entrepreneur stands on a balcony of the observation tower, using a teal-colored laser pointer to highlight key data points on a holographic projection of financial statements floating in the air. The projection is slightly transparent, with the mountain range visible behind it. He’s confidently presenting the numbers as if addressing potential investors.
scenes.templateHTML: What Investors Expect

scenes.heading: Know Your Numbers Cold
scenes.narration: Have a credible path to profitability. Know your margin, burn, and runway cold.
scenes.visualDescription: An Asian man entrepreneur sits at a desk littered with holographic financial projections and sketches within the Observation Tower. He holds his head in his hands, but with a confident smirk, as if he finally has a firm grasp on the numbers. The desk is bathed in the orange sunset light streaming through the panoramic windows. He is now in total command of his data.
scenes.templateHTML: Know Your Numbers Cold

scenes.heading: How Big Is Your Opportunity?
scenes.narration: What's your market size? It's one of the first questions investors ask.
scenes.visualDescription: A Middle Eastern woman entrepreneur stands confidently on an observation deck of the tower, gazing through a telescope at a sprawling cityscape below. Teal holographic rings highlight potential market segments on building clusters. The sunset reflects in the telescope's lens, illuminating her face. She's adjusting focus, a determined look in her eyes, assessing the full scope of the visible opportunities. A glowing teal overlay displays the words "Market Size" on the telescope's housing.
scenes.templateHTML: How Big Is Your Opportunity?

scenes.heading: Market Size Matters
scenes.narration: A brilliant product in a tiny market is a hobby. An adequate product in a massive market can become a billion-dollar company.
scenes.visualDescription: A White man entrepreneur sits hunched over a table strewn with miniature model buildings inside the tower's observation lounge. He's meticulously arranging and categorizing them - tiny skyscrapers in one area, smaller homes in another. He wears a headset, listening to a podcast discussing market dominance. An amber light streams through a panoramic window, casting long shadows highlighting the contrast between the massive and miniature markets. He is taking notes on a nearby tablet.
scenes.templateHTML: Market Size Matters

scenes.heading: The Three Market Circles
scenes.narration: TAM is the whole ocean — the entire global market for your product or service.
scenes.visualDescription: A Hispanic woman entrepreneur uses hand gestures to illustrate concentric circles projected on a holographic display in front of her. The largest circle, representing TAM, encompasses a vast starfield. She points outward, emphasizing its boundless nature. The orange sunset glows from behind the display, creating a silhouette of her figure. Teal lines highlight the circumference of the TAM circle.
scenes.templateHTML: The Three Market Circles

scenes.heading: SAM: Your Fishing Ground
scenes.narration: SAM is your fishing ground — the portion you could actually serve with your business model.
scenes.visualDescription: An East Asian man entrepreneur stands inside a glass-walled section of the observation tower. He's gesturing towards a holographic map of a coastline projected on a nearby wall, highlighting a specific area marked as "SAM." He wears waders and holds a stylized fishing rod. The teal highlight emphasizes the analogy, showing how this area concentrates the market.
scenes.templateHTML: SAM: Your Fishing Ground

scenes.heading: SOM: Your Realistic Catch
scenes.narration: SOM is what you can realistically catch given your resources and competition. This is your near-term target.
scenes.visualDescription: A Black woman entrepreneur sits at a high-tech workstation within the observation tower, manipulating a 3D model of a fishing net on a holographic screen. The net, representing SOM, is sized appropriately to catch a fraction of the fish within the SAM fishing ground visualization. She wears augmented reality glasses that overlay the model onto her real-world view. She is carefully reviewing revenue projections.
scenes.templateHTML: SOM: Your Realistic Catch

scenes.heading: Top-Down Sizing
scenes.narration: Top-down starts with industry research reports and filters down by geography, segment, and business model.
scenes.visualDescription: A White woman entrepreneur in a business suit stands before a holographic data stream cascading down a wall inside the observation tower. The data represents industry research reports. She's using hand gestures to filter the information, focusing on geographic regions and market segments. Teal lines highlight the filtering parameters on the data stream. She is making notes on a tablet, organizing the data.
scenes.templateHTML: Top-Down Sizing

scenes.heading: Bottom-Up Sizing
scenes.narration: Bottom-up builds from your customers and price point. Count potential customers, multiply by price, then by purchase frequency.
scenes.visualDescription: A South Asian man entrepreneur sits at a table covered in customer surveys and pricing sheets within the tower. He's calculating potential revenue by multiplying the number of customers by the average price and purchase frequency. He uses a calculator as he builds his "bottom up" market analysis. An amber sunset light illuminates his work area, creating a focused workspace.
scenes.templateHTML: Bottom-Up Sizing

scenes.heading: Best Practice: Use Both
scenes.narration: Use both methods — if they converge, you're onto something solid.
scenes.visualDescription: A Black man entrepreneur stands between two holographic projections. One shows the "Top-Down" market sizing model, the other shows the "Bottom-Up" model. He's looking back and forth between them, checking for consistency and overlap. Teal lines connect the two models where the data converges. He has a look of satisfaction on his face.
scenes.templateHTML: Best Practice: Use Both

scenes.heading: Real Example: Pet Food
scenes.narration: For a pet food subscription: TAM is the entire US pet food market at $50 billion.
scenes.visualDescription: A Hispanic man entrepreneur uses a holographic projector to display a giant image of a bag of pet food inside the observation tower. He is using hand gestures to outline the packaging of the product. In the background, teal lines highlight the statistic "$50 Billion TAM" on the wall. He is pointing towards the holographic image and nodding his head.
scenes.templateHTML: Real Example: Pet Food

scenes.heading: Narrowing to SAM
scenes.narration: SAM narrows to $1.35 billion for premium dog food targeting health-conscious urban owners.
scenes.visualDescription: An East Asian woman entrepreneur points to a smaller, highlighted region on a holographic map of a city projected inside the observation tower. This region represents the SAM for the premium dog food product. Teal circles pinpoint health-conscious urban owner neighborhoods. The sunset orange light shines through the panoramic windows, focusing on the highlighted SAM region.
scenes.templateHTML: Narrowing to SAM

scenes.heading: Realistic SOM Target
scenes.narration: SOM is $12 million — 10,000 subscribers at $100 per month. That's about 1% of SAM, which is realistic for a startup.
scenes.visualDescription: A Middle Eastern woman entrepreneur stands before a holographic display projecting a graph representing her company's projected subscriber growth. She uses hand gestures to highlight the SOM target of 10,000 subscribers, representing a 1% market share. The graph shows a realistic growth trajectory, not an exponential curve. She looks confident and assured.
scenes.templateHTML: Realistic SOM Target

scenes.heading: The 1% Fallacy
scenes.narration: Avoid the 'if we get just 1% of China' fallacy. Why would you get that 1%? Investors see through this immediately.
scenes.visualDescription: A White man entrepreneur is shaking his head emphatically while standing in front of a holographic projection of the Great Wall of China. Teal lines cross out the projected image. He is dismissively waving his hand, rejecting the "1% of China" fallacy. The orange sunset light casts a dramatic shadow behind him, emphasizing the importance of his message.
scenes.templateHTML: The 1% Fallacy

scenes.heading: Be Credible
scenes.narration: Investors have seen thousands of pitches. They know fantasy versus grounded analysis. Be ambitious but realistic. Show your math.
scenes.visualDescription: A South Asian woman entrepreneur addresses a group of holographic avatars representing potential investors inside the observation tower's briefing room. She gestures towards a display of financial projections and market analysis data. She is emphasizing the credibility and grounded analysis behind her pitch. The setting sun casts a warm glow on the presentation, highlighting the professionalism of her delivery.
scenes.templateHTML: Be Credible

scenes.heading: The Buyer's Journey
scenes.narration: Every customer goes through a journey from not knowing you exist to becoming a loyal advocate.
scenes.visualDescription: A Middle Eastern woman entrepreneur stands before a massive holographic projection of a winding mountain path, each curve labeled with stages of the customer journey: Awareness, Consideration, Decision, Action. She traces the path with her finger, a thoughtful expression on her face. The communications station's control room hums with activity in the background, engineers monitoring data streams. Teal accent lighting highlights the holographic path, emphasizing its complexity.
scenes.templateHTML: The Buyer's Journey

scenes.heading: Understanding the Journey
scenes.narration: Understanding this journey determines what you should be doing at each stage to move them forward.
scenes.visualDescription: A South Asian man entrepreneur sits at a console, reviewing customer journey maps on multiple monitors. Each map represents a different customer persona. He highlights key touchpoints and identifies areas for improvement using a stylus. A holographic overlay shows a flowchart of potential customer paths. Outside the station window, a satellite dish pivots towards the sky, symbolizing data collection.
scenes.templateHTML: Understanding the Journey

scenes.heading: The Four Stages
scenes.narration: Awareness — they realize they have a problem. Consideration — they're comparing options.
scenes.visualDescription: An African American man entrepreneur is presenting to a team in the station’s briefing room. He is pointing to a split-screen display. One side shows a magnified image of a brain representing awareness and consideration, the other a hand reaching for a product. The team leans in attentively, taking notes on tablets. Radio waves emanate from antennas in the background.
scenes.templateHTML: The Four Stages

scenes.heading: Decision & Action
scenes.narration: Decision — they're ready to choose. Action — they buy and hopefully become advocates.
scenes.visualDescription: A Hispanic woman entrepreneur celebrates a sale on a large screen, arms raised in excitement. A cascade of confetti graphics rains down on the screen. Her team cheers alongside her, high-fiving and smiling. In the background, a graph shows a hockey stick growth curve, representing the ideal customer acquisition trajectory. The helipad outside flashes teal.
scenes.templateHTML: Decision & Action

scenes.heading: The Marketing Inflection Point
scenes.narration: The marketing to sales handoff typically occurs between Consideration and Decision.
scenes.visualDescription: A White man entrepreneur stands in the middle of the Communications Station’s control room, gesturing urgently with his hands. One screen shows a sales representative struggling with a lead, while another displays marketing analytics lagging behind. He is barking instructions into a headset to optimize the handoff timing. Red and green indicators highlight potential bottlenecks in the lead flow.
scenes.templateHTML: The Marketing Inflection Point

scenes.heading: Timing the Handoff
scenes.narration: Too early wastes sales time. Too late means hot leads go cold.
scenes.visualDescription: An Asian woman entrepreneur is analyzing data on a monitor displaying a heat map of website engagement. She identifies a critical point where potential customers are dropping off and adjusts the marketing campaign parameters in real-time. The screen shows intent signals flashing as she fine-tunes the handoff process. A technician in the background calibrates a sensor on a radio tower.
scenes.templateHTML: Timing the Handoff

scenes.heading: Watch for Intent Signals
scenes.narration: Watch for active intent signals like pricing requests, demo bookings, or specific implementation questions.
scenes.visualDescription: An African American woman entrepreneur studies a holographic projection of a customer profile, intent signals like demo requests and pricing inquiries highlighted in teal. She is using voice commands to filter and analyze the data, identifying patterns and prioritizing leads. The communications station's AI assistant provides recommendations for personalized outreach.
scenes.templateHTML: Watch for Intent Signals

scenes.heading: Awareness Stage Actions
scenes.narration: At Awareness, provide valuable content. Capture their email in exchange for value. Start a nurture sequence.
scenes.visualDescription: A White woman entrepreneur reviews content marketing performance on a dashboard displayed across several screens. She is selecting a new blog post and social media campaign to promote to a specific customer segment. The screen visualizes the "nurture sequence" as a branching path with tailored content for each stage.
scenes.templateHTML: Awareness Stage Actions

scenes.heading: Consideration Stage Actions
scenes.narration: At Consideration, build trust with case studies and social proof. Invite them to webinars or demos.
scenes.visualDescription: A Hispanic man entrepreneur is hosting a live webinar, presenting case studies and social proof to potential customers. He gestures enthusiastically to the screen displaying testimonials and success stories. Attendees type questions into the chat, displayed in a scrolling ticker. Outside the window, a drone broadcasts the webinar signal to a wider audience.
scenes.templateHTML: Consideration Stage Actions

scenes.heading: Decision Stage Actions
scenes.narration: At Decision, make it easy to say yes with clear proposals, guarantees, and appropriate urgency.
scenes.visualDescription: An Asian man entrepreneur reviews a final proposal on a tablet, highlighting a guarantee and an urgency discount. He is making a video call to the customer, exuding confidence and professionalism. The backdrop shows a mission control style room, emphasizing the importance of closing the deal.
scenes.templateHTML: Decision Stage Actions

scenes.heading: Be a Guide, Not a Closer
scenes.narration: The buyer's journey isn't something you create — it already exists in your customer's mind.
scenes.visualDescription: A Middle Eastern woman entrepreneur is using a sophisticated sensor to scan the mental landscape of a potential customer, represented by glowing neural pathways. She is adjusting her approach based on their existing beliefs and motivations. The screen shows a heatmap of their needs and pain points.
scenes.templateHTML: Be a Guide, Not a Closer

scenes.heading: Meet Them Where They Are
scenes.narration: Your job is to understand it and meet them where they are. That transforms selling from pushy to helpful.
scenes.visualDescription: A Black man entrepreneur kneels, offering a helping hand to a customer avatar struggling to navigate the mountain path represented by the customer journey. The avatar is clearly relieved and accepts the guidance. The entrepreneur smiles warmly, illustrating the transformation from a pushy salesperson to a trusted advisor. The summit pavilion glows in the distance.
scenes.templateHTML: Meet Them Where They Are

scenes.heading: The 7-Second Rule
scenes.narration: You have about 7 seconds to capture someone's attention. In that brief moment, they're deciding whether to keep listening or move on.
scenes.visualDescription: A Middle Eastern man entrepreneur sits hunched over a complex control panel in the communications station, frantically adjusting dials. Alarms flash red as a digital timer on the main screen counts down to 0:07. Sweat beads on his forehead. Outside the panoramic window, a rocket launch is aborted, smoke billowing around the pad.
scenes.templateHTML: The 7-Second Rule

scenes.heading: Your First Impression
scenes.narration: Your hook is that first impression — it either pulls them in or pushes them away. It's the gateway to every conversation and conversion.
scenes.visualDescription: A White woman entrepreneur strides confidently through the communications station, her tablet displaying a split-screen of a welcoming website design on one side, and a broken, confusing one on the other. The good design glows with teal accents, while the bad one is dark and cluttered. She gestures emphatically towards the welcoming design.
scenes.templateHTML: Your First Impression

scenes.heading: The Goal
scenes.narration: A great hook makes the right person think: 'That's me. Tell me more.' And it helps the wrong people self-select out — which saves everyone time.
scenes.visualDescription: A South Asian man entrepreneur in the comms station, wearing a headset, leans back in his chair, smiling. In front of him, a large holographic display shows silhouettes of diverse individuals, with a spotlight focusing on one figure highlighted in teal. The other silhouettes fade into the background.
scenes.templateHTML: The Goal

scenes.heading: The Online Hook Formula
scenes.narration: For websites, social media, and ads, use the WHO plus WHAT plus WHY formula. This structure ensures clarity and impact.
scenes.visualDescription: A Black woman entrepreneur stands before a whiteboard in the communications station, diagramming the "WHO + WHAT + WHY" formula with colorful markers. Arrows connect the elements, visually emphasizing the flow and structure. A small group of onlookers watch, nodding in understanding.
scenes.templateHTML: The Online Hook Formula

scenes.heading: WHO - Your Ideal Customer
scenes.narration: WHO is your ideal customer, described specifically. Not just 'business owners' but 'overwhelmed service business owners.'
scenes.visualDescription: A Hispanic man entrepreneur uses a holographic projector to enlarge a detailed 3D model of his "ideal customer" - a frazzled service business owner juggling multiple tasks on a virtual treadmill. The model is surrounded by visual representations of stress – swirling notifications, missed calls, and overflowing inboxes.
scenes.templateHTML: WHO - Your Ideal Customer

scenes.heading: WHAT - The Transformation
scenes.narration: WHAT is the transformation or result you provide. What changes for them? What do they get to do or achieve?
scenes.visualDescription: An East Asian woman entrepreneur stands proudly next to a holographic display showing the transformation her product delivers: A split-screen depicting a chaotic, unorganized office transforming into a streamlined, efficient workspace, visualized with glowing lines connecting tasks and personnel.
scenes.templateHTML: WHAT - The Transformation

scenes.heading: WHY - The Deeper Benefit
